They served a plurality of gods. We find that there were certain things with regard to their religion and certain things with regard to their practice that God is speaking of and He says to His people, I've brought you out of Egypt, but I want you to understand and I want you to be mindful that those things which you observed, the doings of the land of Egypt wherein ye dwelt, notice these four words, shall ye not do. He goes on, And after the doings of the land of Canaan, whither I bring you shall ye not do, neither shall ye walk in their ordinances. As you understand here that the children of Israel are kind of in a position in which they've left Egypt and they're not quite to the land of Canaan yet, they're in this in-between time, and we understand that the children of Israel, as you look at the scriptures and you understand that they will not, of course, as you look through the book of Numbers, they will not believe God, they will not go over, there's this period of wilderness wandering, so on and so forth, and God, however, here in the book of Leviticus, as He's preparing them, they've exited from Egypt, He's trying to prepare them for dwelling in Canaan. And He says there's some things that you observed in Egypt, you're not supposed to do those things, there's some things that you're going to observe in Canaan, you're not supposed to do those things. You'll note that on two occasions in verse number three, that the Bible says shall ye not do. It's pretty clear, is it not? And so we understand that as we would take note of verse number three, that there are some things that are forbidden and we would note that as we go throughout the next couple of chapters in particular, that God will very explicitly go through details of things that they shall not do. Not only does He tell them what they shall not do, but He shares with them what the consequences of such actions would bring.
